Award.AwardTitle: Noncommutative Distributions in Free Probability at the Fields Institute; July 1-31, 2013 at the Field Institute in Toronto, Canada
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of U.S participants in the program "Noncommutative Distributions in Free Probability at the Fields Institute" that will be held from July 1-31, 2013, at the aforementioned institute in Toronto, Canada.

The theme of this wide-ranging program is free probability and its ramifications. Free probability theory is a probability theory adapted to deal with variables having the highest degree of noncommutativity. It is based on replacing independence modeled on tensor products by independence modeled on free products. The theory has important connections with von Neumann algebras, random matrices, combinatorics, and certain problems in mathematical physics. Surprisingly, the part of basic classical probability theory for which there are free probability analogues is unexpectedly large and keeps growing. The program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Free probability is a highly noncommutative probability framework, which combines methods from several fields: operator algebras, combinatorics, classical probability, random matrices.
Young mathematicians working in this field are usually trained in an environment where some , but not all of the sides of the subject are emphasized. It is therefore important that they have the opportunity to attend free probability events where they have the opportunity to meet other researchers in the field, learn, communicate, exchange experiences, present their results.  The major goal of the project was to support travel and accommodation for young US mathematicians to participate in the program "Noncommutative Distributions in Free Probability" at the Fields Institute in Toronto in July 2013. Residual funds were then used for for partial support for the same category of junior US mathematicians to participate in related free probability events, including to give talks in the UC Berkeley Probabilistic Operator Algebra Seminar organized by the PI. Ten young US mathematicians with support from the grant participated in the Fields Institute program. During an extension period of the grant four young US mathematicians travelled to Berkeley to give seminar talks, with partial support from the grant. Finally nine young mathematicians received partial support from residual funds to attend and give lectures about their work in an Extended Probabilistic Operator Algebra Seminar at UC Berkeley (May 8 - 11, 2015) and three more received travel support for other free probability events. At the Fields Institute several of the young mathematicians gave lectures at the workshops about their work and there was also an especially designed two weeks period between workshops for students and postdocs, which provided excellent training and professional development opportunities. At the later free probability events for which partial travel support was extended, all the young mathematicians supported gave lectures about their research work. Looking back, the support provided by the grant has clearly had the desired impact in helping the development of the young mathematicians as researchers and has made a human resources contribution.
